timeline.bodyText: I'm not sure about this .... we need to check that if the dir should not be persisted then anything that is already in it should be removed before we try and unpack the webapp into it.
timeline.author: janbartel

replies.bodyText:
But we cannot remove it arbitrarily here, only under small circumstance will removing the directory itself be safe.
This step isn't really necessary as both the WebInfConfiguration.deconfigure() and the Temp directory specific File.deleteOnExit() both cover the deletion angle.
As an alternative, we could simply clear out the directory contents.
replies.author: joakime

replies.bodyText: yep I think we need to clear it out
replies.author: gregw

replies.bodyText:
Yes, I'd prefer to clear out the directory contents, and leave the dir in place.
This is safeguarding if the previous deconfigure() failed, and deleteOnExit might not come into play because you're just restarting the context/server without restarting the jvm.
replies.author: janbartel

replies.bodyText: The temp directory deletion block has been restored.
replies.author: joakime

replies.bodyText:
About the concern about prior directory (example given is context/server restart) ...
The Files.createTempDirectory path (or the older File.createTempFile path), this delete would never have deleted the prior directory, as each time you enter this block you have a new directory path.
replies.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText: You need to keep the if (!context.isPersistTempDirectory) dir.deleteOnExit.

replies.bodyText: Scratch that, i'm wrong about this specific one.

replies.bodyText: No, it's also called directly by resolveTempDirectory in the case where someone has explicitly supplied the temp directory to use or the javax.servlet.context.tempDir has been set - whether these are persisted or not is optional and configured by configureTempDirectory.
replies.author: janbartel

timeline.bodyText:
You've changed the logic here.   This was always deleting and recreating a non persistent temp dir.
We  don't want to do that any more because of hijacking!   But I think we have to ensure the tempdir is empty if it is not persistent.
